channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Europe’s Leaders Ditch Austerity and Fight Pandemic With Cash
item.description: As Britain and the European Union respond to a public health emergency and economic crisis, they are abandoning dogmatic frugality and embracing Keynes.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Bank of England. Britain is not hesitating to open its wallet to attack the crisis.

item.title: White House Considers Postponing Tariffs to Help Businesses: Live Updates
item.description: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Damir Sagolj/Reuters
item.media:description: An iron and steel plant in Chongqing, China.

item.title: A $2 Trillion Coronavirus Stimulus Will Help, but More May Be Needed
item.description: The bill moving through Congress is more than twice as large as the stimulus package passed in 2009, but it will soothe a shutdown economy for only a few months.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Bryan Derballa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nearly empty Fifth Avenue in New York City on Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: Essential? Retailers Like Guitar Center and Michaels Think They Are
item.description: Some chains are loosely interpreting what it means to be a critically important business.
item.dc:creator: Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sears has given workers letters saying they are conducting “essential business” and therefore exempt from “emergency closure orders.”

item.title: A Sewing Army, Making Masks for America
item.description: With overrun hospitals facing an acute shortage of masks, people are pulling out their sewing machines to fill the void.
item.dc:creator: David Enrich, Rachel Abrams and Steven Kurutz
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Corinna Bakken, the Minnesota Opera’s costume director in Minneapolis, stitching masks out of gowns sent by a local hospital.

item.title: Nurses Share Coronavirus Stories Anonymously in an Online Document
item.description: A health care worker in New Jersey created a digital venue for people in the field to chronicle poor working conditions that may put patients at risk. “It is disgusting,” one nurse wrote.
item.dc:creator: Edmund Lee
item.media:credit: Krissy Breece
item.media:description: Sonja Schwartzbach started compiling the accounts after she determined that hospital conditions were “far worse” than most people realized.

item.title: Inside American Airlines’ Scramble as Virus Grounds Jets by Hundreds
item.description: Nearly every part of the airline, the largest in the United States, has been transformed, and executives are fighting to keep it afloat.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Nick Oxford/Reuters
item.media:description: American Airlines is canceling 40 percent of its flights each day.

item.title: In World’s Most Vulnerable Countries, Coronavirus Pandemic Rivals the 2008 Crisis
item.description: As capital flees emerging markets, those countries are absorbing the most potent economic shocks of the coronavirus outbreak.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman, Daniel Politi, Suhasini Raj, Lynsey Chutel and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Prambanan temple complex in Yogyakarta, Indonesia, is closed to the public.

item.title: North Macedonia Awaits Marijuana Laws to Become a 'Cannabis Superpower'
item.description: Vying to become Europe’s “Cannabis Superpower,” marijuana entrepreneurs in the recently rebranded country are waiting for the government to act.
item.dc:creator: David Segal
item.media:credit: Loulou d'Aki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pharmacon employees tending to “mother” plants.

item.title: When Your Restaurant’s Star Dish Is Blamed for Spreading Coronavirus
item.description: As restaurants around the world close or retool to enforce social distancing, Hong Kong’s hot pot eateries offer a cautionary tale and some good advice.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Yu
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bong Kwok and Jason Ho prepare a takeout order at their hot pot restaurant in Hong Kong.

item.title: White House Weighs Tariff Delay
item.description: The Trump administration is considering postponing tariff payments on some imported goods for 90 days as part of its response to a faltering economy
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: The White House previously issued narrow exemptions to eliminate tariffs on surgical gowns, masks, gloves, hand sanitizer and other medical products in response to the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Can You Become Immune to the Coronavirus?
item.description: It’s likely you can, at least for some period of time. That is opening new opportunities for testing and treatment.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Xinhua/Alamy Live News
item.media:description: A recovered coronavirus patient donated plasma at the Hainan Blood Center in Haikou, China, in February.

item.title: The Fed Asks for BlackRock’s Help in an Echo of 2008
item.description: BlackRock will advise the Federal Reserve on the purchase of billions of dollars in bonds and securities. The terms of the agreement were not disclosed.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Gabriella Angotti-Jones/Bloomberg
item.media:description: BlackRock, which manages nearly $7 trillion in assets, will assist the Federal Reserve’s efforts to stabilize the bond market.

item.title: Ventilators and Coronavirus: Amid Desperation, Calls Grow for Federal Intervention
item.description: President Trump wants the private sector to fill the urgent need for the lifesaving devices. Experts say that strategy may doom the thousands who will need them in the coming weeks.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs, Neal E. Boudette, Matt Richtel and Nicholas Kulish
item.media:credit: Angus Mordant/Bloomberg
item.media:description: A lone ventilator at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on Monday in New York, which will be converted into a 1,000-bed hospital.

item.title: Gilead Withdraws Request for Special Orphan Status on Experimental Coronavirus Treatment
item.description: Critics said the company was profiteering from the coronavirus pandemic by seeking tax and monopoly benefits under a program intended to encourage drug development for rare diseases.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Economic Crisis Prompts a Showdown, and a Shutdown, in Suriname
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic is but one factor in a confrontation between the South American nation’s business sector and its authoritarian government.
item.dc:creator: Harmen Boerboom and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The streets of Paramaribo, Suriname, as it confronted a deepening economic crisis.

item.title: Big-Name Hotels Go Empty and Smaller Owners Are Hurt
item.description: More than 90 percent of the hotels in the U.S. are franchised, and these owners say their business has been devastated by the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vinay Patel owns nine hotels in Northern Virginia. He has begun laying off employees.

item.title: Trump’s Coronavirus Briefings Are a Ratings Hit. Should Networks Cover Them?
item.description: The president’s viewership has rivaled the audiences for hit reality shows and prime-time football. But some worry about misinformation.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump facing reporters at a White House briefing on Tuesday. The updates have attracted an average audience of 8.5 million on cable news.

item.title: Lawmakers Question Start-Ups on At-Home Kits for Coronavirus Testing
item.description: The makers of unauthorized kits designed for consumers to collect their own saliva or throat swabs faced scrutiny from Congress.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:description: Everlywell said it would provide its kits to health care providers and hospitals.

item.title: When to Restart the Economy?
item.description: Wall Street executives have warned the Trump administration of another Great Depression if Americans don’t get back to work soon.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Oliver Contreras/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: President Trump yesterday with Dr. Anthony Fauci of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.

item.title: ‘A Week of Snow Days’? Ha! Families Deal With Cabin Fever
item.description: As people become hostages in their own homes, hired clowns and costume nights may not be enough to maintain sanity.
item.dc:creator: Nellie Bowles
item.media:credit: Sarah Mazzetti

item.title: Coronavirus Decimates N.Y.C. Taxi Industry: ‘The Worst It’s Ever Been’
item.description: Drivers have contended with Uber and inflated medallion prices. Now the pandemic has caused rides to plummet by two-thirds or more.
item.dc:creator: Winnie Hu and Nate Schweber
item.media:credit: Stephanie Keith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many drivers have seen their income plunge as passengers have all but disappeared.

item.title: Roosevelt Avenue Goes Dark
item.description: A bustling commercial corridor in Queens prepared to shut down as residents adjusted to their new reality.
item.dc:creator: Todd Heisler

item.title: The Dos and Don’ts of Online Video Meetings
item.description: From setting a clear agenda to testing your tech setup, here’s how to make video calls more tolerable for you and your colleagues.
item.dc:creator: Brian X. Chen
item.media:credit: Glenn Harvey

item.title: Trump May Defer Tariff Payments to Help Businesses
item.description: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, center, with other officials on Capitol Hill.

item.title: Shutdown Spotlights Economic Cost of Saving Lives
item.description: President Trump and others have asked if halting normal life and commerce to fight the coronavirus is worth the cost. Here’s how economists figure it.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Porter and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Chona Kasinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Downtown Seattle was virtually empty on a Friday in mid-March after the region became a U.S. beachhead for the new coronavirus.

item.title: The Oversight Playbook From 2008 Returns as Bailout Swells
item.description: Lawmakers are eyeing the appointment of a new inspector general to keep tabs on Treasury’s $500 billion “slush fund.”
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has become the face of the giant stimulus package being discussed in Congress, with Democrats insisting on some type of mechanism to prevent fraud and abuse.

item.title: Drivers Say Uber and Lyft Are Blocking Unemployment Pay
item.description: States like New York and California have made gig workers eligible for jobless benefits and sick days. But the companies have resisted complying.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:credit: Jessica Pons for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerome Gage, a Lyft driver in Los Angeles who has lost most of his business, faces difficulty collecting unemployment benefits.

item.title: With Kids Learning From Home, Children’s Publishers See a Spike
item.description: As schools close during the coronavirus crisis, sales of reading and writing workbooks, flash cards and activity books have skyrocketed.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Ian West/PA Images, via Getty Images

item.title: Stanley Sporkin, Bane of Corporate Corruption, Dies at 88
item.description: As the S.E.C.’s enforcer, he targeted firms that made illegal campaign contributions in the U.S. and bribed officials to gain business in other countries.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:credit: Teresa Zabala/The New York Times
item.media:description: Stanley Sporkin in 1975. As the chief enforcement official at the Securities and Exchange Commission, he helped turn the agency into a scourge of miscreant corporations.

item.title: Medicare Is Updating Coverage to Help in the Coronavirus Crisis
item.description: With its beneficiaries among the most at risk for Covid-19, the agency is relaxing some rules.
item.dc:creator: Mark Miller
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:credit: John Moore/Getty Images
item.media:description: Health care workers handling a coronavirus test at a drive-through station in Stamford, Conn.

item.title: Facebook Is ‘Just Trying to Keep the Lights On’ as Traffic Soars in Pandemic
item.description: The social network is straining to deal with skyrocketing usage as its 45,000 employees work from home for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Facebook’s 45,000 employees have been asked to work at home during the pandemic, emptying the offices.

item.title: The Stock Buyback Binge May Be Over. For Now.
item.description: Companies are hitting the pause button on share buybacks, which have suddenly become politically and financially unpalatable.
item.dc:creator: Matt Phillips
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Companies in the S&P 500 stock index spent more than $2 trillion buying back their own stocks over the last three years.

item.title: The ‘Blurred Lines’ Case Scared Songwriters. But Its Time May Be Up.
item.description: Decisions in copyright cases involving Led Zeppelin and Katy Perry suggest the open season on lawsuits could be coming to a close.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:credit: Helle Arensbak/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The Led Zeppelin frontman Robert Plant last year. A court of appeals upheld a jury’s verdict that Led Zeppelin’s “Stairway to Heaven” didn’t copy Spirit’s “Taurus.” The case has big implications for music copyright lawsuits.

item.title: As Businesses Close, WeWork Tries to Lure Workers Back
item.description: The shared office space company is offering its workers $100-a-day bonuses to go to its locations amid the coronavirus crisis.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Sangsuk Sylvia Kang for The New York Times
item.media:description: WeWork’s shareholders are arguing over the terms of a bailout of the office space company by SoftBank.

item.title: To Fight the Coronavirus, Cut the Red Tape
item.description: Two economists suggest suspending these 5 types of regulations because they are slowing the medical response to the pandemic. And they are asking for more ideas.
item.dc:creator: Sendhil Mullainathan and Richard H. Thaler
item.media:credit: John G Mabanglo/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A coronavirus testing center in Hayward, Calif.

item.title: Some Doctors Stockpile Trial Coronavirus Drugs for Themselves, States Say
item.description: The stockpiling has become so worrisome that pharmacy boards in many states have issued emergency restrictions on how the drugs can be dispensed.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Gabler
item.media:credit: Ramin Rahimian for The New York Times
item.media:description: A handful of state pharmacy boards have issued emergency restrictions on how the drugs can be dispensed.

item.title: The Evening News Is Back
item.description: The network newscasts had lost relevance, thanks to cable and digital media. Now, the coronavirus has put tens of millions of viewers back in the 6:30 p.m. habit.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin
item.media:credit: NBC
item.media:description: “Nothing else matters right now,” the “NBC Nightly News” anchor, Lester Holt, said in an interview. “This is the story of our lifetimes.”

item.title: Coronavirus Spurs a Wave of Suspect Websites Looking to Cash In
item.description: Hundreds of e-commerce sites are popping up daily to sell virus-fighting products. Many are being shut down for making exaggerated claims or selling phantom products.
item.dc:creator: Michael H. Keller and Taylor Lorenz
item.media:description: Shopify has registered nearly 500 new e-commerce sites over the past two months with names that include “corona” or “covid.”

item.title: Bohemian or Business: Identities Collide in Miami’s Coconut Grove
item.description: The city’s development boom has finally caught up to a lush haven of shade trees and cafes. Some worry the neighborhood growth is too fast.
item.dc:creator: Jane Margolies
item.media:credit: Angel Valentin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The twisting, 20-story residential towers of the Grove at Grand Bay.

item.title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
item.description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Peiser

item.title: Restarting the Economy Is About Lives Versus Livelihoods
item.description: President Trump signaled that he’s open to lifting restrictions soon on social distancing in an effort to restart the U.S. economy.
item.media:credit: Alex Brandon/Associated Press
item.media:description: President Trump yesterday with Dr. Deborah Birx, right, the White House coronavirus response coordinator, and Attorney General Bill Barr.

item.title: Is Pausing Contributions to SEP I.R.A.s a Good Move?
item.description: Self-employed workers use the vehicles to save for retirement. As the coronavirus concerns build, taking a break could be smart.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns
item.media:credit: Till Lauer

item.title: One City’s Road to Recovery Offers Lessons, and Hope
item.description: Lawrence, Mass., once an industrial power, set out to reverse a long decline with the Federal Reserve’s help. Now it faces a new economic challenge.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Porter
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Lawrence, Mass., received a $700,000 grant over three years from the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston.

item.title: Marijuana and Coronavirus: Is it an 'Essential Business?' Some States Say Yes
item.description: In most cases, marijuana businesses must, like restaurants, limit themselves to takeout or delivery. Black-market dealers are also busy, but feel little need to abide by official orders.
item.dc:creator: Dan Levin
item.media:credit: Jeff Chiu/Associated Press
item.media:description: Cali Manzello, general manager of the Apothecarium, a cannabis dispensary in San Francisco, wears gloves as he handles marijuana samples in the store.

item.title: You’ve Got Mail. Will You Get the Coronavirus?
item.description: The practice of disinfecting mail dates back to the invention of quarantine. There’s little evidence it needs to be invoked today.
item.dc:creator: Nicola Twilley
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mail carrier in Manhattan on Monday.

item.title: Some Pregnant Women in New York City Will Have to Deliver Babies Alone
item.description: “I have not stopped crying,” said an expectant mother who learned that her husband could not be with her when she gives birth.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron and Katie Van Syckle
item.media:credit: John Minchillo/Associated Press
item.media:description: NewYork-Presbyterian has barred partners from labor and delivery rooms throughout its network.

item.title: Live Stock Market Coronavirus Updates and Tracker
item.description: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Tom Pennington/Getty Images
item.media:description: American Airlines on Friday carried out its first cargo-only trip in 36 years.

item.title: 3 Newspapers Ask China to Reverse Decision to Expel American Journalists
item.description: The publishers of The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post released a statement critical of China’s revocation of Americans’ credentials.
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Steven Lee Myers, the New York Times Beijing bureau chief and one of the American journalists being expelled by the Chinese government, at the Beijing bureau on Tuesday.

item.title: Start-Ups Jump the Gun on Home Kits for Coronavirus Testing
item.description: After a federal warning, companies have stopped marketing kits that let consumers collect their own saliva or throat swabs and send them to labs.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: On Friday, Nurx, an online health start-up, said it had run out of self-swabbing kits for the coronavirus. Nurx later suspended sales after the F.D.A. said it had not authorized such kits.

item.title: Trump Considers Reopening Economy, Over Health Experts’ Objections
item.description: The president is questioning whether stay-at-home orders have gone too far. But relaxing them could significantly increase the death toll from the coronavirus, health officials warn.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley, Maggie Haberman and Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Stephanie Keith for The New York Times
item.media:description: As large swaths of the economy shut down to contain the coronavirus, President Trump and others are beginning to question how long economic activity should remain frozen.

item.title: Bankers Pledge Mortgage Help, but Want Billions
item.description: Millions of borrowers may be unable to make payments on home loans next week. The mortgage industry says it’s willing to help, but needs the government to back it up.
item.dc:creator: Emily Flitter and Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mortgage groups said Monday that their plan to give borrowers a three-month break would require $36 billion to shore up the mortgage markets.

item.title: As Fox News Played Down the Coronavirus, Its Chief Protected Himself
item.description: The cancellation of an 89th birthday party for Rupert Murdoch highlights a disconnect between his family’s behavior and statements made on air by some Fox commentators.
item.dc:creator: Ben Smith
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/Getty Images
item.media:description: Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of Fox News, with his son Lachlan Murdoch in 2017.

item.title: The Coronavirus Revives Facebook as a News Powerhouse
item.description: More than half of all news consumption on Facebook in America is about the virus, according to an internal report.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose and Gabriel J.X. Dance
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Millions of Americans are rediscovering Facebook and using it to connect to their family and friends during a time of isolation.

item.title: Whatever It Takes: How the Fed Aims to Rescue the Economy
item.description: The central bank is using tactics from the last financial crisis and deploying new ones to keep money flowing. Here are the basics.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Yuri Gripas/Reuters
item.media:description: The Federal Reserve, under Jerome H. Powell, is moving to shore up the American economy during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Local News Outlets Dealt a Crippling Blow by This Biggest of Stories
item.description: Layoffs. Canceled print editions. Weekly papers and small dailies across the country face peril as the coronavirus cuts off ads and live events.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu and Marc Tracy
item.media:credit: Whitney Curtis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Copies of Riverfront Times, a local weekly, stacked inside a closed coffee shop in St. Louis.

item.title: Coronavirus Patients in Limbo as Gilead Suspends Emergency Drug Access
item.description: The company says it will switch to a broader approach for its experimental drug, remdesivir. But it was overwhelmed by demand for a potential treatment promoted by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
item.media:description: Gilead Sciences headquarters in Foster City, Calif.

item.title: There Is a Racial Divide in Speech-Recognition Systems, Researchers Say
item.description: Technology from Amazon, Apple, Google, IBM and Microsoft misidentified 35 percent of words from people who were black. White people fared much better.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amazon’s Echo device is one of many similar gadgets on the market. Researchers say there is a racial divide in the usefulness of speech recognition systems.

item.title: Obamacare Turns 10. Here’s a Look at What Works and Doesn’t.
item.description: With the coronavirus, a new Supreme Court case and a blistering election debate, the Affordable Care Act is facing challenges as never before. We looked at how it’s held up to its promise.
item.dc:creator: Abby Goodnough, Reed Abelson, Margot Sanger-Katz and Sarah Kliff
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Obama signing the Affordable Care Act into law at the White House on March 23, 2010.
